title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
text:
Background
As someone who really loves good food, I unfortunately am a really lazy cooker. Exhausted after a long day, I have a small roster of really simple recipes that I follow. Some of my friends more passionate and skilled in cooking have started using ChatGPT to find high-quality recipes, so now I wonder: can GPT do this for really easy, low-level recipes as well?

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
section: GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesnâ€™t care much for food
text:
GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesnâ€™t care much for food
Prompt: Iâ€™m a tired, hard-working college student. Please develop or refer me to easy recipes for me to cook.
Response: Got it â€” you want easy, low-effort recipes that work for a tired college student. Iâ€™ll give you a mix of super quick meals, one-pan recipes, and no-fuss snacks. All of these can be made with cheap, common ingredients and minimal cooking gear.



GPT first response


From this simple prompt, GPT output a very, very expansive variety of options for me to choose from. But one very important thing was missing from the recipes that I requested: no steps. Even for really simple recipes such as egg fried rice, there is still is a certain amount of knowledge required that (I assume) most people with little cooking experience would know. For example, which ingredient goes into the pan first?
I was a little surprised that GPT was missing these steps, since Iâ€™ve also used GPT for lab protocols or software help such as with (used often in research) ImageJ. And with minimal prompting, GPT would do a very in-depth breakdown of every single step to take.
Prompt: Include steps please
Perfect â€” let me turn those quick ideas into step-by-step recipes so you can follow them even when youâ€™re tired. Iâ€™ll keep them short and no-nonsense.



GPT second response


Well I must admit that this egg fried rice recipe seems pretty similar to what I do at home, except itâ€™s missing some essential aromatics (garlic and ginger) that barely lengthen the preparation. This recipe seems more akin to something that white Americans would cook (no offense), but this makes sense as I am using an English language LLM who would take recipes from those who write in English. And Americanized Chinese food recipes absolutely drown out the few Chinese cooks out there in the English recipe blogging community
Side note: From the original prompt saying I was tired and hardworking, GPT clearly assumed that meant I was also in a rush and not in the mood for flowery prose (perhaps someone who doesnâ€™t care the finer details in cooking). Which, is likely but not necessarily true for students like this, so itâ€™s interesting to see how GPT thinks further ahead with these assumptions to cater towards the user.
Overall, GPT seems decently sufficient at generating these recipe ideas and I can completely bypass the extremely long and annoying prose that always takes up more space than the actual recipe on most websites. However, GPT lacks specificity without prompting, but thatâ€™s something that can be easily remedied. Something I might try in the future is plugging in what random ingredients I actually have in the fridge and see if GPT is able to generate a working recipe from that. But Iâ€™ll save that for a future blog.

title: First Test
text:
YinYangCats.jpg


Iâ€™m testing out uploading a post here. I also tested uploading an image. No AI was used in the creation of this post.
Hi! My name is Suya and I am a senior studying bionengineering. Iâ€™ve seen how much AI and its usage has evolved over the past few years, especially in education, and Iâ€™m excited to better understand the machinations behind this evolution. Fun fact: my favorite animal is the cat, hence the picture (credit: Pinterest)!

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purpleâ€¦
But it is possible you first said green (donâ€™t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


Itâ€™s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | â€” | â€” | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It getâ€™s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. ðŸŸª

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, Iâ€™ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
